unnormalised: I've been seeing a lot of confusion online about where to send official documents, especially when dealing with government and institutional offices. It's definitely a tricky thing, especially with the way addresses are sometimes written in India. I remember once, I had to send an application form to the "Office of the District Magistrate, Civil Lines, Allahabad, UP, 211001". I almost sent it to a random residential address because the format wasn't what I was used to!

unnormalised: The main thing to remember is to pay close attention to the details. For instance, "Reserve Bank of India, Shahid Bhagat Singh Road, Fort, Mumbai, Maharashtra, 400001" isn’t just "RBI Mumbai." You need that full address, including the pin code, for it to actually reach the right place. Then there was the time my cousin needed to apply for a scholarship and the address was something like "The Registrar, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Mehrauli Road, New Delhi, 110067." Very specific!

unnormalised: Often, you'll find that official addresses are longer and more formal than what you're used to seeing for personal correspondence. They usually include a designation (like "The Director"), the name of the institution, the street name, the city, the state, and the pin code. For example, "The Principal, Kendriya Vidyalaya, Sector 8, Rohini, Delhi, 110085" is a typical school address you might need.

unnormalised: Another thing that can be confusing is when the office is located within a larger complex. You might see something like "The Superintendent of Police, CID Headquarters, MG Road, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560001." Make sure you include the building name or department, if applicable, as part of the address.

unnormalised: So, my advice is to always double-check the address on the official website or document before sending anything important. It’s way better to be safe than sorry and avoid any postal mishaps! A small mistake could mean delays or even lost documents. Good luck navigating the world of Indian addresses!
